Another mass meeting to be held in the interest of guod roads, the next fair, advertising and other kindred subjects. The Civic League has recently held its annual meeting and organized for another years work. The most practical civic league ever organized in town was the outcome of a suggestion made in the local paper 25 years ago. document.text: Woman Captured Prisoner. It is rarely indeed that a woman claims a regard offered for the appre hension of a criminal. Such a claim was not only made, but was substan tiated and paid by the State, on .order of the Governor. The recipient of a warrant for 100 is Miss Anne Norvell, of Charlotte Courthouse. She captur ed Eli Morton, a negro who had shot an officer, and turned him over to the custody of the law. There was mtach excitement a few months ago when Morton wounded the town sergeant at Charlotte, while the officer was at tempting to arrest him. Bloodhouqds were rushed from the State Prison Farm. It seems that Miss Norvell saw the fugitive, and, intent on captur ing him, invited him into her house. When he entered she locked him in and Immediately summoned the min trict. document.text: William Pitzer Gills, who died at his home, Locust Grove, Friday morning, was the son of James Thomas and Cornelia Terri 1 Pitzer Gills. Though jiorn in Buckingham county, he moved to Appomattox in his boyhood on account of the death of his father. He then made his home with his uncle, the late Will iam Gills, who for many years was treasurer of the the county. He at tended the first public school evei taught in this county, Judge David A. Christian being the teacher. Mr. Gills engaged in various aeti- ties until the infirmities or age made, it necessary for him to retire from, public life. He was a senool trus.et of Appomattox county also serving as clerk to the school board, man carrier on R. F. D. No. 2, employed at one time by the Norfolk and Wes tern Railway, besides managing his arm near Appomattox. He was a iason and a Woodman of the  orld, and a Democr t who was un- werving in his par loyaly. Fii nany-lyears he was a faithful dea- on of Liberty Baptist church and teacher in the Sunday School. The deceased was a man whose lie was marked by fidelity to prin- ple. His was a goodly heritage of u ture and Godliness from an an cestry distinguished in the early history of America. Those who came in con4act with him were impressed by the deep spirituality of his nature. t  The funeral took place Sunday afternoon at Liberty Baptist church The Rev. H. Frederick Jones, the pastor, and the Rev. William May- field Thompson, a former pastor, conducting the services. The choir ,f the church sang Mr. Gills favor ite hymn, Rock of Ages. Tenny sons immortal poem, Crossing the Bar, was read and played on the pipe organ as a processional. Inter ment took place in the family plot in Liberty Cemetery, that part of the service. being conducted by the Masonic order. A host of friends and acquaintances, with many beautifa floral tributes attested to the love and high regard in which Mr. Gills was held in Appomattox and through out the state. Ihe active pallbearers were A. T. Inge, C. S. McDeormon, R. L. j Burk?, A. R. Harwood, J. C David son, N R. Featherston, B. G. An derson, Luther J. Morris. Honorary pallbearers included R. B. Hudgins, J. H. Lucado, T. W. Moses, Charles T. Moses, Pat Chand ler, L. Crawley, C. W. Smith, W. Stratton Taylor, Jennings Ferguson. T. Ed Owen, W. J. LeGrand, Dr. D. A. Christian, Dr. C. G OBrien, S L. Ferguson, Jr., J. H. OBrien, W. B. Caldyell, F. L. Murphy, E. VR-y Smith, Andrew Wingfield, H. C. Pul iam, Uoel Flood, Don Moses, John T. Cole, J. W. Caw son, John A. Iweedy, R. W. S an- ey, H. M. Burge, R. Travis Lee, F. A. OBrien, R. Edward OBrien, VV. W. OBrien, T. H. Inge, M. C. Imith, S. Guy Smith, R. C Wagner, J. A. Burke, Charlie Johnson, Pit zer Johnson, William Burke, D. A. Conner, D. E. Turnes, Jesse L. Tumes, James W. Caldwell, Harry Jenkins, Leonard Carter, E. Percy Sea, Odel! Howerton, Edmund H. Cawthorn, O. Cleveland Paulette. T. Morton Rosser, R. W. Smith, Leslie N. Ligon, L. E. Smith, C. N. Abbitt, J R Horsley, J. E. Chick, W. L. Brown, L. F. Ferguson, O P. Farrar, J. H. Cheatham, Dr. L L. Gayle, Dr. C. F. James, Robert Hubbard, Fitz Martin, Calvin H. Robinson, George F. Abbitt, Jr., T. W. Ferguson, Lester B. Harvey, J. D. Plunkett. Mr. Gills was first married to Miss Ella Pittman, who died some years ago. Two of the children of this union survive him, Henry Pitzer Gills of Marion, Virginia, and Mr 3 . Luth er B. Pittman, of Richmond. His second wife, who survives him, was Miss Albertha OBrien Of this mar riage, six children wire torn, James, passing away in inf.-ncy. The five living are Professor Allen Gils, of Clarksville Miss Cornelia Kyle Gills, of Appomattox Shelby Ken- nard Gills, of Richmond Mrs. Will iam Haller Copenhaver, of Marion Mrs. R. Banks Frazier, of Richmond. He also leaves five grandchildren, Mrs. R. S. Simpkins, of Chrisians- burg, Va. Mrs. Allen B. Pearcy, of Bristol, Penn. Joseph Pitzer Gills, of Pulaski, Va., Eloise Ogden, and Mary Joan Gills, of Clarksville, Va., and one brother, James T. Gills, of Lynchburg, his only other brother being the late Edmond Ernest Gills, of Appomattox.  And death itself, to him, was but The wider opening of the door Tha had been opening, more and more, Through all his life, and nevei as stiut. . . .

document.text: when the little crowd of five girls was making fudge at K itty Bentons, she told them all about it, half-unconscious- ly attributing to the unfortunate Stu arts the qualities possessed by the peo ple in the story. There is a girl, she informed them, and I think she is about our age. 1 suppose she will attempt to buy her w ay into our crowd. She will wear better dresses than any of the rest of us, and she will think that just because she has more money than w e have that it is her place to lord it over us. Now, w e must show her that the old fam ilies of this town are not going to suc cumb to mere wealth. We must be quite oblivious to her guady display. It is fortunate we understand the situ ation before she comes, for now she will be given no opportunity to hu miliate us. All of this made a deep impression upon the four other girls. Marion, be cause she w as the most imaginative of the crowd, had become in a sense its leader. She had a peculiar, quick w ay of assimilating the things she read, and that made her companions feel that Marion had attained to a very deep understanding of life. The first day Caroline Stuart walked down the main street of Elmwood, they felt their suspicion that she would attempt to  lord it over them to be confirmed. Her gown bore the marks of a city dressmaker, and she walked very straight and carried her head very high. That w as partly because she had been1 taught to do so at school, and in part because, feeling timid with so many strange eyes upon her, she sought refuge in dignity. Her impulse was to look with friendly interest at the five girls as she passed- them, but feeling shy, she looked straight ahead instead.  Well, of all the airs! gasped Marion. It is evident that she feels miles above us! sputtered K itty Benton. We will not trouble her, comment ed Doris Morton, with dignity.  Its just as I told you, insisted Marion.  Now the only thing to do to let her absolutely alone. They did. When she passed them upon the street they were deeply ab sorbed in one another. They studied the art of passing her house without nowing it was there. When she be- gan driving in her pretty pony-cart they regarded it as a personal affront, The strange part of it all is that they ere in truth kindly girls, and would have felt very badly indeed at the idea of hurting any ones feelings. Their attitude bad grown upon them to such an extent that with the coming of tbe big red automobile, the first to be seen in Elmwood, the ignoring of Caro line Stuart had become a duty. Perhaps few girls of her age have ever passed as unhappy a summer as Caroline Stuart passed that year. Of warm-hearted, sunny nature, she was girl to whom friends were a neces sity. She was so free from any idea of distinctions created by money that the secret of the thing never dawned upon her. She supposed, on the other hand, that the girls did not like her. It was a beautiful day in September, and her young, naturally buoyant heart made her wish to get outdoors and be doing something, even if she must do it by herself. W ill and her father had gone in the automobile to an adjoining town, and her mother was lyiug down with a headache. So she started out alone to drive up the winding river road which skirted the edge of the woods. The country round Elmwood was very beautiful, and Caroline threw herself into the spirit of the day, tell ing herself that some time, in some other place, she would find friends to enjoy the world with her, and that meanwhile she would try to enjoy it by herself. She was succeeding in getting more pleasure out of the drive than had been hers for a long time, when sud denly she heard laughing voices, and peering through the trees, saw the five girls into whose friendship she had at one time supposed she would be taken They were spreading a cloth upon the grass and opening some parcels. She watched them through dimmed eyes until they sat down and began to eat, The, when she could bear it no longer, she whipped up her pony and started briskly up tho road. The day had lost its charm. She did not see the woods and the river and the soft sky. She kne,w only that the world seemed a hard, lonesome place, and that her heart was yeafning for friends and companionship, for the kind of fun those girls were having. It was very near the same spot that upon lier return, a half-hour later, she saw Marion Foreman and one of the other girls helping K itty Benton down to the river. It was evident that some thing had befallen hoi-, for she was hopping on one foot, and moving as if it pained her. Caroline guessed at ouce that the girl had sprained her ankle, and that they were helping her to the big. flat rock close to the river. They did not notice her until she was near them, so near that she heard Marion call to the girl behind,  Of course this had to happen the very day we walked instead of drove! and then they glanced up and saw her, and looked with studied care out at the river. Caroline drove by, her heart heating very fast. Every instinct prompted lier to offer to drive K itty Bentou back to town. But would they accept the offer? Would they not think a tie was trying to intrude, and tell her in so many words that they did not care to have anything to do with her? Of course they wouid, and she would not go hack. But the idea of leaving nnv one in trouble when It was within

document.text: When the 1975 RAILROAD ESTIVAL PARADE gets underway at 10 a.m. Saturday, October 11, an endeavor of the . Appomattox Junior Womans Club and the Town of Appomattox, music, beauty, listory and elected leaders local, state, and national will e featured. United States Senator Harry Flood Byrd, Jr. will be the Parade Grand Marshall leading the parade behind the music of the Appomattox County High School Band. Senator Byrd, a native of Winchester, received his edu cation at Virginia Military Institute and at the University of Virginia. A veteran of World War Q, he was elected to the Senate of Virginia six times serving from 1948 to 1965. Byrd was appointed to the United States Senate in November of 1966, was elected in 1966 as a Democrat lor a four year term and was reelected in 1970 as an Independent for another six year term ending in 1977. He is the second person in history to be elected to the U.8. Senate as an Independent candidate. A member of the Democratic State Central Committee from 1940 to 1966, Chairman of the , Virginia Advisory Board on Industrial Development from 1962 to 1967, he is publisher of a number of daily newspapers in the vklley including the Winchester Star. He is the son of the late Harry Flood Byrd, a former U.S. Senator and the grandson at Mrs. Bolling Flood Byrd who was born and raised in Appomattox. Immediately following the parade. Senator Byrd will participate in ceremonies held on the platform at the Depot and will be the guest speaker. Seventy-two entries are slated to march in Saturdays parade as Artie Levin, well known television celebrity, participates as Master of Ceremonies for the 1,975 parade. The parade will depart from Virginia Department of High ways parking lot at 10 a.m. and will follow a route along Morton Lane, Court Street, down Main Street, will go up Church Street, along Highland Avenue back to Court Street, then along Ferguson Street to the Appomattox Primary School where they will disband. This 1975 parade should bo the grandest ever in Appomat tox and most certainly will be the largest.

document.text: Wednesday, Sept. 25, has been set as moving day for the Appomattox County Depart ment of Social Services. New quarters are in the lower section of the recently erected county office building on Morton Lane. The office will be closed Wednesday, Thursday and Friday while the transfer is being made. Regular office hours will be resumed on Monday. Sept. 30.

document.text: Webster Morton, a Washington negro who was shot by Detective Ser geant Louis R. Kellam while resist ing arrest, died at the City Hospital, Richmond. Morton, who was 25 years of age and very powerful, was a mes senger for the Washington and South ern Bank, of Washington, and left that city with 6,000 of the funds of the hank.

document.text: We need more of just such men in public place. If we had more of them ia Washington we would soon haveUacle Sam looking after his public roads over which his earners move day after day, and at tmes when they are a standing disgrace to a civilized people. Mr. Davis Morton is building a new barn on his farm just east of town and is directing the work in person. It is a most desirable pro perty and some day he will have a model farm of it. But Farmville may grow so rapidly in that direc-1 tion that he may be induced to cut the acres up into town lots. And yet when some of our truckers are selling a thousand dollars worth of stuff from an acii it may be better to cultivate acrae than to cut them into town lots. The old Confederates were with us on Saturday in larger numbers than before on such occasions, for though the ranks are thinning those who still answer the roll call are more certain to respond to such oc casions. They marched in a body to the monument on which stands that silent sentinel like a Stone- j wall to toll of the courage, and en durance, and splendid loyalty of days that tried mens siuls, and ith uncovered heads saluted. Be- turn was made to the Opera House, and there Miss Mary Jackson wel comed them warmly and eloquently, Miss Lockett Walton read an origi nal poem, redolent of sweet senti ment Hon. Don P. Halsey moved them with his eloquent plea for a monument to the South, and then the dinner followed. And to say that it was a Southsidr Virginia dinner in conception and execution gives assurance that it was not only fit for the gods but the heroes who so much enjoyed it. More than one of the number remarked  How we would have relished such a meal in the last days of the war. But seated at such a table after a days march might have been as danger ous as going into battle. Crosses of Honor were bestowed npon a num ber of the survivors, and when the curtain fell on the program of the day it was agreed that it will live in memory as one of the best in the series. The Baccalaureate sermon, which was preached last evening before the graduating class of the Normal by Bev. Geo. E. Booker, of Petersburg, was a gem of fervid an impressive oratory. With  Life as the theme the gifted man of God drew sharp distinction between the false and true life and urged the better way. The audience was a large and in spiring one and the occasion one of thrilling interest. Tonight will t o given over to Class Night and to morrow Mr. Byrd, of Wincuester, will address the graduates.

document.text: Washington.Women opposed to suffrage will launch a great drive to defeat all enemies. They declare it is their purpose to fight fire with fire. They will go in equal suffrage States and urge the antis there to swat every candidate who has helped to thrust the vote upon them. We are determined and prepared to defeat all tools of feminism and double suffrage, said Mrs. David Holmes Morton, of the New Yorlt Woman Voters Anti-suffrage Party. There are many States where women now have the suffrage by State action, and those opposed to suffrage have in their possession an effective weapon with which to an nihilate politically ny candidate for public office who has had a hand in imposing suffrage on women any where. The campaign of .the antis will ex tend to every State where women now vote. Anti-suffrage women in each of these States are being urged by letter and personal appeals to register and vote against that candi date for office who has been most prominent in his or her efforts to in flict suffrage on the country. Blacklists will he issued. They will carry the names of those slated for slaughter at the polls. The advance program formulated by Mrs. Morton says that voting for Cox or Harding is bad any way you take it. I would further suggest, said she. that as between the Presi dential candidates it is a choice of wo evils. We should support the Democratic ticket In Republican States and the Republican ticket in Democratic States and pursue the same policy as to other offices, mak ing it the rule to oppose for re-elec tion any suffragist even if his op ponent is unsound on the question. Punish each one for what he has done and attend to the other fellow next time. One lesson will he enough in both cases. The politicians have figured on the antis refraining from active opposition. Here is the opportunity of giving them the kind of jolt they will take to heart.

document.text: Washington, Special. Secretary of the Navy Morton desires to leave public life as soon as possible, and by July 1 he will have relinquished his present post to some other man and will in ail proba bility have gone to Europe for a brief stay. Mr. Morton is now weighing the re spective advantages of at least four im portant position in business life which have been offered to him. Not all of these are railroad positions. Secretary Metcalf is expected to suc ceed him, and it is reported that if Mr. Metcalf does not get the Navy post he will in all probability retire from public life. He is not a wealthy man. Secretary Morton replied to the com munication received by him from the Humane Society of the City of Galves ton, Texas, in which they call attention to the alleged inhumane treatment of the crew of the cruiser Galveston during the recent stay of that ship at Galveston. Mr. Morton says that the facts related constitute the most ample excuse for any unlawful action which any commanding officer of a naval vessel might take to preserve order and discipline.

document.text: Washington Letter. From our regular Correspondent. W ashington . Feb. 22nd, 1897. Hon. W. J. Bryan will visit Wash ington this week,but he will not prob ably stay untill Inauguration day. He will be the guest of Mr. John R. McLean, who will giye a dinner to about one hundred guests in his honor. This dinner will not be a political event, as the guests will in clude a number of personal friends of Mr. Bryan in all the parties.  Bnt-ikiring Mr. Bryans slay their I will be a conference, perhaps several, to discuss the immediate future ol the democratic party. Senator Daniel, of Va., is one of he best elocutionists in the Senate consequently Washingtons farewell address, which, in accordauc with the usual resolution was read imme Ldiately after the Senate convened, in honor of Washintons birthday. 1 8 much better rendered than- usual, and was listened to by an un usually large number of Senators, j in addition to the crowded galleries. It is unfortunate in more senses than obe that there should be a-i I investigation at this time into an act of the administration by which the step-father of the Presidents j wife will be largely benefitted. And! everybody sincerely wishes that the! Senate Committee on Public Lands will find everything straight about the Florida land patent for 23,000 lucres, which was recently issued to Mr. Perriue, the husdand of Mrs. I Clevelands mother, and which the Committee is now investigating. Ex Congressman Brookshire of In diana, is counsel for the settlers on this land, who claim that the grant was forfeited many years ago.  The Civil Service Commission has made answer to Senator Allens res olution, adopted by the Senate last week, as to the alleged dismissal of two women from a branch of the Agricultural Department, at South Omaha, Neb., for displaying pictures j lot Mr. Bryan in the late campaign. The answer says the Commission investigated the complaint when first made and that Secretary Morton denied that the discharges were! made for the cause specified, or tha I he knew the politics of those dis- I charged. The most significant por tion of the answer, especially to I those in office who regard themselves as being protected by the Civil Service Commission, is the following The Commission is not i an appointing, or reinstating, or removing body. Representative McRae, of Ark., who was one of the democratic mem bers of the coingage committee wbo I voted for the favorable report, with amendments, of the Senate bill auth orizing the President to appoint del egates fur any international nione  tary conference, called by any na tion or by himself, took occasion to I briefly state the attitude of the democrats toward the bill. He said the democrats had no faith whatever in such a method of. bring ing about the free coinage of silver, I but that they had no desire to place any obstacle in the way of the repub licans trying to carry out the prom ise made by their national platform   on the contrary, that they were anx ious for the next administration to demonstrate to the country what could be done along that line. Notwithstanding Senator Kyles assertion that he did not get the republican votes which reelected him by making promises, the repub- licaus in Washington are now count- mg upon his voting with them to obtain control of the Senate organi zation and to fill Committee vacan cies that will exist March 4th This confidence of the republicans 13 not bied upon any vague expec tation or hope they do not say Sen ator Kyle may vote with us, bin that Senator Kyle will vote with us In voting with the republicans in this particular case, should his vote settle the question, Senator Kyle will betray the principles he has professed ever since he entered the! Senate. As most people know, the Senate finance committee, as at pres ent made up, is controlied by silver although seven of its thirteen mem- bers, including the chairman, are republicans. There will be two vacancies in this committee on March 4th. Senator Sherman will enter the Cabinet and Senator Voorhees will retire to private life. The re publican leaders consider it necessary as this is the committee that will handle the new tariff bill, that both of these vacancies shall be filled by men .who can be counted upon to support the new tariff bill and to oppose any silver legislation that niay be proposed and they are say ing that Senator Kyle, whose advo- cacy of silver and free trade is widely known, will vote with them. If he does what will be the natural infer ence ? Representative Walker, of Mass, couldnt upset the Reed rules, but he conld and did express himself very vigorously on the subject, sav in part Under the rules of this House, we get mighty few rights. When you goto see about  bill, you are referred to a sub committee, and then you may cool your heels there day after day before you can get so much ar one member nf the snb- committee to bear you. And when you do he tells you he knows all about it and intimates that you are boring him. Then when he reports and -vou trJ to appeal to the fuU committee, yon get no satisfaction. He called this a sys tem of tyranny, and adned much more to the same effect.

document.text: Washington. D. C. Special.The announcement was made at the Navy Department that Rear Admiral Sigslices squadron will he sent to France to bring back the remains of John Paul Jones. Th is squadron consists of the cruis ers Brooklyn. Chattanooga, Tacoma, and Galveston. All hut the last named ves sel are in Dominican waters, hut will proceed shortly for New York to fit out for a trip across the Atlantic. The Galveston is being fitted out at the Nor folk yard. It is estimated at the department that Admiral Sigsliee will sail from New York between the jth and 10th of June. At the last Cabinet meeting Secrc- Tary Morton brought to the Cabinrts attention the subject of tbe dispo  m of the remains of John Paul Jones, t.ic President directed Secretary Morton to send a naval vessel to France to bring the remains of the first admiral of the American navy to the United States. President Roosevelt approved the rec ommendation of Secretary Morton that the body of John Patti Jones be buried at Annapolis. Mil.

document.text: Washington. D. C. Special.Sec retary of the Navy Morton has admitted that he expects to leave the Cabinet before the cold weather conies again. He experts to go hack to his old place with tile Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe uailway, as the place he relinquished before entering the Cabinet has not been filled since 1 u resigned. It is thought here that Mr. Morton, about the 1st of July, will find it con venient to retire, and some say he would go before that time, except for the rea son that tile newly appointed Assistant Secretary of the Navy, Mr. Newberry, who succeeds Mr, Darling, has not taken office yet. and it is desired that he be come acquainted with, the duties before the Sceretary himself retires.

Special. allowing sensational charges made flhy officers of the Washington Milk Dealers Association that a multi millionaire milk trust is seeking to oontrol the milk supply of the large cities in order to establish a monop oly for the manufacture of pasteur- falug machinery. Attorney General Wlckersham ordered an investiga tion. The charges were made at a hearing before the District commis sioners, held in connection with a campaign that is being waged by the fnk producers against pasteuriza ción and the turerculin test. At this hearing Corbin Thompson, vice-president of the dealers as sociation, and A. S. Trundle, chair aban of the executive committee, barged that an alleged gigantic trust, headed by Levi P. Morton, Thomas F. Ryan and Anthony Brady mad including a number of the fore most financiers of the country, sought to control the milk supply in order to sell their pasteurizing machines, ad to thij end were bringing pres- cure to bear on the health officers of targe cities. At the hearing there were present adcntlsts from -he various govern- sncnt departments in Washington and veral of them were named as being directly or Indi.ectly Influenced by ghe trust. document.text: was accustomed to say, no matter who left Farmville was sure to come back. Mr. Warren Walker owns the old Spencer homestead in the eastern portion of the ton, and when he has given it the finishing touches it will be one of the most attractive properties in the place. Mr. Lucian Bugg Asst Cashier of the firat National Bank, has bought a handsome residence on High Street This is the coming residence street of onr town, and will be madg more attractive when the new walk-way h is been finished. Work on the new Methodist church has been inaugurated and until the structure has been com pleted the congregation will wor ship in the opera house. Hampden Sidney did the proper and handsome thing in conferring the L. L. D. on President Jarman, of the Normal. Dr. Hale, of the William k Mary faculty, who will conduct the summer institute at this place, was first to arrive on the ground and enter upon his work with win ted enthusiasm. M ísb Mary Beckley has gone to Winchester where she will teach in the summer Normal for the month of July. Governor Swanson will appoint a number of new members of the Board of the State Female Normal, and that may mean some changes in the offi cial staff. Mrs Jarman and the children are in Greenville, Tenn., where they are visiting Mrs. Wily, the mother of Mrs. Jarman. The citizens who live at Rice De pot are not at all pleased that so many of the N.  W. passenger trains fail to stop there. A social event of more than us ual import takes pla e today when Miss Genevive Racon Venable, of Farmville, becomes the bride of Dr, Walker Morton Holliday, of Hamp den Sidney. After a brief wedding tour they will be at home on College Hill. Dr. Holliday enjoys au im mense oractice and is held in high esteem by a host of friends and patrons, while Farmville has given no fairer or more attractive daugh ter to the bonds of matrimony than is the one, who to-day becomes his wife. Postmaster Buggs salary has been increased from 1900 to 2000  Watch Farmville grow. The announcement that Profea sor Whiting, of Clarke county, has been re-electe 1 a member of the Hampden Sidney faculty, gives genuine and general satisfaction. He acted as President after the re signation of Dr. McIUwain, and made a fine impression on students and community. There has re cently been introduced into the management of that venerable school of learning enough young blood to give new thrill of life as well as secure trolley line connec tion with Farmville and through Farmville the rest of the world. Applications for s miner board jp Farmville are numerous

document.text: warm and loving wi Iconic to the Methodist brethern. These services will continue during the months of July and August. Rev. Mr. Little ton also occupied the pulpit and took part in the service. Mr. C. A. Pri-e and family will occupy a portion of the home of Vlrs. Wade for the coming Normal session. There are some 125 students in attendance upon the Summer Nor mal, SO of whom board at the Nor mal, with Mary White Cox ii. charge. Our authorities are urging for new granolithic walkways, aud 1 suppose when they have finished with the town they will begin Work on the public roads leading into, town. The dispensary is au up-to- date road builder, and none of us are  looking the gift horse in the mouth. I feel sympathy for the cooks who have to stand over the cook stove in weather like this, but I am very grateful to them for tneir faithful ness. Mrs. C , R. Morton and her daughter, Miss Loulie, are at Crocketts Springs. Mrs. P. W. McKinney and Miss Frankie, are at Blue Ridge, Supt. Eggleston addressed the Summer Normal on last Thuisday evening aud a reception followed.  Rev. Mr. Matchott, who is sup plying tiie Episcopal pulpit, is preaching most acceptably to mem bers of that congregation. Our livery horses are suffering on the road during the heated term. The soda water man is all smiles with the thermometer in the nine ties. Our doctors are n it busy, the health of our people being unusually good. Our preachers will have their usual vacation. The small boy is enjoying the river, and the older boy the bath rooms. Our fathers little dreamed thai Farmville would one day be sup plied with telephones,electric lights, bath rooms and granolithics, and who ever dreamed that one dispen sary would whip out five saloons ?

Fortunately no one was hurt Our Supervisors are i y see sion today. Settled with Treas urer and a good balanoe is in his hands. Lieutenant Luther Throck morton, of Richmond, is a guest in the home of Mr. Jerry Burke. Mr D. R. Puckett went to Lynchburg Sunday to see his wife, who is in a hospital there. She is reported to be able to sit up, which will be good news to the many friends of the family. Evangelistic meetings are in progress at Liberty Baptist ohnrob. Rev. F W. Putney, of Norfolk, is doing the preach ing. He is a man of wonder- nl pulpit power and grips and îolds his audience from begin ning to end. The attendance lias already overflowed the arge auditorium and almost filled the Sunday, school room. Mr. Putney will preach twice a day,at 11 a. m. and 8.00 p. m., dosing Sunday night. Boys And girls from Appo mattox county wishing ac commodation at the school dor mitory, bad better apply to Principal Crawley, as many applications from other coun ties are coming in. It now lookB as if this will be the best year of any. If all come who lave applied for admission, more room will be needed to take care of the crowd. I have a direct call for a young man graduate of this school as Assistant County, Agent of Prince William coun ty. Any one interested will call on L. Crawley.

document.text: W e would like to bring the public up to date on the progress of the  Appomattox situation. A meeting be tween the company and representatives of the workers was held last Saturday with several towns people present in cluding Congressman Abbitt and Mayor Buchanan. The meeting was chaired by Mr. Morton, a federal conciliator assigned to this situation to help settle it. After meeting with both sides separately, M r. Morton called a joint meeting of the company and worker repre sentatives. Mr. Morton asked us what the conditions were under which we would return to work. W e told him we wanted a raise in pay, better treatment and a settlement of all pending grievances. W e also offered the company the services of our unions engineering department to help man

document.text: W e have been so fortunate as to spend the past ten days with rela -1 tives and friends in this good old 1 country and have enjoyed anew The good old time befo de war. I It wbh a novel, though most ageable sensation to be so far from I the railroad that we could not bear the train blow, and the vespite was most beneficial to tired nerves. At Pamplins we spent several hours most delightfully with thej family of Rev. W. E. Warren and Dr. and Mr. C. S. Morton, friends of other days. The drive from Pamplins over beyond Putneys was very pleasant, but we missed the mail boxes along the way. Crops  of all kir.ds are good, especially to bacco and fruit abundant. One lady said there had been over a hundred bushels of peaches gat bar -1 ed from her orchard, and every -1 w h ere such quantities of beautifull flowers we never saw. It was our I good pleasure to be just in time fori th e dedication of the new house of I worship of the Douglas Presbyte-I rian church. It is indeed a beuuti-l ful building and reflects great cred -1 it on the architect, Mr. Frank Allen of Tredway. He is an elder in the church and did roost of the work himself. This good old county is I the very plant bed of Presbyteri an, and of all the host of people we met, we shook hands with only four Baptsts and one Methodist. It was a saddened joy to sit in that vast congregation and look aiound in search of familiar faces,II and there were very few whom we recognisedthe boys and girls with whom we bad had such goodtimesl twenty-eight years ago are staid I men and women now with grown I children, and in some cases grand children, around them, and the hair that was once brown or black I is now streaked with grey. We felt a stranger in a strange land ! But when we visited them in their I home it came to us afresh that! Though sundered far by faith w ell meet around one common mercy   Beat. It was a blessed privilege to meet I with Mrs. Letitia McDearmon, Allen I the last of the old McDearmon I family of Appomattox. She has! raised a large familyeight sons I and five daughters, all members of I the Presbyterian churoh and are! filling positions of trust and re -1 responsibility in the church and I county. She is in her 83d year, I and is quite feeble, and as we held! her trembling hand at parting we I thought it would not be long be -1 fore she would hear the Well done I of her Master, whom she has sol faithfully served and enter into her reward. At Felden, near Hampden Sidney we enjoyed meeting with Sargeant Rchard Allen, who served all through the Mexican and Civil wars It was indeed a treat to listen to his reminiscences. He is in his 83d year and is still very fond of hunt ing. We heard much in praise of Dr. McAllister, the new president of Hampden Sidney, and it is thought the number of students at the col lege will largely exceed that of last year. At Prospect we met with an old Appomattox friend, Mrs. Wm. Lew is. How our tongues did fly as we talked of the past, present and fu ture, and all too soon we heard the train that was to take us home. There are other things we would like to write about, but to tell of all the pleasure that was crowded into those ten days would make this letter too long. After all the most pleasant sound we heard while gone was the conductors Evergreen and we realized that in a short while we would be at home, for there is no place like home es pecially if home be in d ar old Ap pomattox.

document.text: W ashington, D. C., Special. President Roosevelt made the fol lowing announcment regarding chang-  es in the Cabinet William H. M oody of M assachu setts, to be Attorney General. Paul Morton of Illinois, to be Sec- 1 relafy of the Navy. Victor 11 . M etcalf of California, to be Secretary of Commerce and Labor. The resignations of Secretary Cor- teiyou and Attorney General Knox j have been received and accepted, to  take effect July 1. j Mr. M orion was in Washington ast week and took lunch at the W hite House,  nen the President offered him the secretaryship of the navy, it having been determined at that lime j to put Representative .uetcalf at the  head of the Departm ent of Commerce  and Labor. Iv.r. Aiortou then declined, and it I was generally supposed that his name was no longer being considered  The President was determined to have J him in the Cabinet, however, if it  could be accomplished, and he has the very highest admiration for Mr. Mor  ton s character and ability. The latter was finally prevailed upon ! o forego his own wishes, owing to ! his regard and friendship for the President. It is expected that further changes will take place in the Cabinet next winter. Postm aster General Payne probably will retire fr im the Cabinet after the campaign. He will be suc ceeded by National Chairman Cortel you. Secretary M oody will continue ! as a member of the Cabinet only until I the end of the present, administration  on the 4th of March next, when he  will retire to enter upon the practise  of law in Boston. it is quite likely that other changes  will take place, even if Mr. Roosevelt ! should be elected President but no authority exists at this time upon which to base a forecast of them. Attorney General Knox, as is well  known, resigned to become Matthew 1 S. Q uays successor in the United i States Senate, having been appointed by Governor Pennypacker. Mr! Knox, 1 who is a prominent Pittsburg lawyer,  has been A ttorney General since April i 19, 1901. ! Mr. Cortelyou resigns to conduct j the Republican campaign, having been elected chairman of the National Com mittee. A lter having been clerk and  secretary of three successive Presi dents, he was, in February, 1903, taken 1 into the Cabinet as head of the newly  established Department of Commerce and Labor. Mr. Moody was a Haverhill lawyet and a Massachusetts Congressman foi  several terms before he became Sec retary of the Navy, on M ay 1, 1902. succeeding John D. Long. Mr. Morton, who is the eldest son of the late J. Sterling Morton, Secre tary of Agriculture in Clevelands second term, is 47 years old. He is a well-known railroad man, and is now vice-president of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad. He is now a citizen of Illinois, and sat in the Republican Convention as the alternate of Speaker Cannon.

document.text: W ashington , Feb. AImmense crowds were drawn to the oapitol today by the formal o-remouies luoidout to the official counting of the ieleetoral vote. The bright sunshine nnd tonio-braoing breezes which marked the day were boldly claimed as Cievelaud weather, aud were sharply contrasted with the dismal atmospheric surroundings which hav.e so unfortunately aocompanied nearly every one of Mr. Harrisons pub lio appeaniuces, commencing with the drenching rain on hto inauguration day, and even following ldm Into eaoh of hto private duok-hunting expeditions. The ceremonies attending the count ing of the vote are prescribed by a joint resolution, reported by Senator Hoar in 1888, and which has been made applica ble to all succeeding elections aud bos been Incorporated in a supplement and revised statutes. Vice-President Morton some days since appointed as tellers On behalf of the Senate for this Im portant ceremony,. Messrs. Hale, of M a in l and Blaokburn, of Kentucky. S p eak e r top appointed Judge Chipman, ot Michigan, and Mr. Henry Cabot Lodge, Srtator-eleot, from Massachusetts, as Hafise teller,. The actual ceremonies wer- nearly the same today as four years agd witU all8hmt ferenoe io the personal?. There was a ceremofilont opening of the cafe ia tbe Viee-reiideuts room sod taking out the eighty-eight ! 4. packages,supposed to..pon.tali the rt.  of forty-four States, a  received in da pMcate by mall and messenger there was a solemn procession iu the Goose Step of old C apiaiotssett, who bas puriiolpated in every presidential count for more than sixty jjftei, escorted by the oapitol police wit prevent a raid being made upon thei prcolpus locked boxes containing tho foies. The boxes having been safely deposited in tbe House, tbe Senate in a body followed shortly before 1 oclock Members of the upper chamber were of coarse received by the House with becominz respect. The Vioe-Presldeut aPcefided the Speak ers platform aud took bis seat at tbe right hand of Speaker Crisp, the Sena- tnis erruuguig themselves in places as- sium-d to them on tbe tight ot the hall, and in this munuiT the court proceeded i-iibe presence of tbe ite.isely packed galfories and the crowded fl tor. The preoed-nts heretofore observed wi le followed and the proceedings pro- rir piitv toHsoerisiiiing the resut. Tne Yu- President having called the j .let ttssembla-.e to order proceeded foiinally to open  ne of the b xes which eo tatned tbe ielurus of tbe electors of th- vailous Stales, Tue first return, ihntof Alatiama.  handed to S .m to r Hale, oue of tbe tell era, who in  lovr, but di-tiut voice, read the siateinentshowing that eleveu votes of ibat Stale bad iweti cart f r Cievelaud aud 8ieveniou. Then ceriilloales were! pieseiited wit hunt a formal reading, tbe teller merely staling Ibe result. Thare was tb utmost diguiiy preserved until T- Her Biackburn announced tbat tbe Suite of Illiuis bad cast twenty-four Votes for Cleveland and Sleveuson. A lew speotator-i broke Into applause, which was promptly obecked by tbe V ce-Pres dent, who, io a few dignified words, celled upon tbe spectators not to di.turb tbn decorum, wblcb ought to characterize tbe great national transac tion which was now proceeding In tbe pre-enenof tbe great American people. Af i r the last certificate had been read and the resoltsfooted up, the Vice- President made the oustomary announce m ent that under the law that this was a sufficient declaration th at Grover Cleve land, of the State of New York, had been elected President of the United States and th at Adlai E. Stevenson was elected Vice-President of the United States, each for a term beginning March 4th, 1893, and that this result would be entered, together with n list of the votes, on the journals of tho 8enate and the House of Representatives. document.text: W a s h in g t o n , D. C., May 31,97. A real investigation of the sugar 8canaalone that would go to the bottom of things and not get fright ened off when on the track of infor mation that would incriminate Sen ators, would be a good and desirable thing to have, but another fizzle like he last would be worse than useless, because it .would do ore harm than good. The people re cognize a job of white-washing as quickly when it is done by Senators as by humbler wielders of the brush. Senator Jones, of Nevada, who was inferentially charged by Senator Aldrich with having given out the sugar schedule before the tariff bill was reported to the Senate, is Chairman of the Committee on Contingent Expenses, to which Till mans resolution for a sugar inves tigation by a committee of five Sen ators was referred, and he says the committee will report the resolu tion favorably. That makes it reasonably certain that the resolu tion will be adopted, because number of Senators who would like to vote against it will not dare to do so. It will all depend upon the formation of the investigating com mittee whether it will mean business or a farce. Senator Tillman will be Chairman of the Committee. If he be given four colleagues as fearless as himself, the guilty Sen itors if there be any such, will be brought to book, and the sugar trust, the bead of which got cleared on that other indictment will also be shown up but if he be given colleagues who are afraid of thei hadows, nothing will come of the investigation. The Republican Steering Com mittee in the Senate is slowly but surely undoing the work of the sub committee that prepared the amend ment to the Dingley tariff bill, and by the time the bill gets through the Senate, the rate of duties imposed therein will aveage almost or quite as high as the Dingley bill. The tax on cea and the increased tux on beer are doomed, and we are likely to have an internal revenue tax on bauk checks, mortgages, etc., in their places, unless the republicans get frightened out of the idek by pro tests. Mr. T. G. Peyton, a well-known Virginia gold democrat, thus sizes up the present situation  It seems to me now that those of us who contribute to the success of the re publican ticket have been the vie tims of a confidence game. As view it now, a very great mistake was made la3t November. It would have been much better for the conn try to have elected Mr. Bryan have not become a convert tv fre! silver since the election, my belief in sound money is as strong as ever but I am satisfied that if Bryan had been elected, the country would have recovered more quickly from the ills that have afflicted it. Senator Morgan was doubtless out of order when he made that stirring attack upon Speaker Reed and the House on the floor of the Senate, but the attack was certain deserved and Senator Morgans assertion that the present methods of the House are not constitutional is receiving close attention, and may result in a change. The selection of Whitelaw Reid vnd his brother-in-law, Ogden Mills, to be respectively Special Ambassa dor and Secretary to the A mbassador to represent the United States at the Queens Jubilee ceremonies in London, is another indication of Mr. McKinleys disposition to cater to the wealthy. Whitelaw Reid, hanks to his father-in-laws money md some never very clearly ex- amed business manipulations, squired a controlling interest in the paper established by Horace Greely and later by political trickery got Levi P. Morton turned down by the republican National Convention and himself substituted for Benja min Harrisons running mate in the last campaign. These may be easons why he should be especially honored, but why Mr. Mills who has never been anything but an idle society man should be honored is explainable on any other ground than that of money-worship on the part of Mr. McKinley.

document.text: Virginia PensionsJames W. Love. Sydnorsville. 6 Addison D. Barrett, Norfolk. 8 John M. K. Anderson, National Soldiers Home, Elizabeth City count-, 8 Fred L. Matteson, Na tional Soldiers Home, Elizabeth .City county, ig Henry L. Cabell, Cedar- ville, 12 Edward W. Goodwyn Mex ican War, .Lunenburg, 12 Christian G. Merritt, Greenville, 12 John Mc- Cartv, Latana, 6 William T.. Clark, Meherrim, 12 Sidney Stout, Luckets.  6  Mrs. Elizabeth C. McKenna died at Charlottesville Wednesday night. A part of the house in which her body ay fell on account of excavations. The workmen narrowly escaped. The observance of .Confederate Me morial Day in Lexington has been set or Saturday. May 23. The chief mar shal will be Col. W. T. Poague, of the Virginia Military Institute. Mrs. Samuel T. Early, wife of S. T. Early, of Alcorn, Miss., died at the ionie of her late father, Mr. Samuel Adair, near New Monmouth, Rock bridge county, aged 40 years. She was martied on Christmas Day. Miss Margater Hockenberry, of Mar- iinsburg, died at the age of 91 years. The old lady arose during the night and began to dress and expired about 30 minutes later. She had retired in her usual health. The engagement of Miss Bena Faun- tleroy Harrison, daughter of Mrs. Pow ell Harrison, of Leesburg, and Mr. Walter H. Taylor, City Engineer at Norfolk, Va., has been announced. The marriage will take place on June 24 at the home of the brides mother. Two large factories owned and oper ated by Suhling  Co., Lynchburg, were destroyed by fife. When the alarm was given flames were issuing from the tops of both structures, and before the firemen got to work all ef forts to save them were hopeless. Many nearby factories were in danger. The Suhling Buildings were connected by an archway of wood, and it is supposed that the fire spread through this. Suh ling  Co. ship annually millions of pounds of tobacco to Germany. The value of the two buildings is about 30,- 300 and of fixtures 10,000. The stock on hand is variously estimated at from 30,000 to 100,000. The loss is about 75,000. While the Messrs. Suhling vould make no statement, it is thought that the loss will be covered by insur- ince. The Norfolk Common Council re fused to approve the action of the Se lect Councils in relieving social clubs tf taxation and adopted Section 152. of the tax ordinance requiring such organ izations to pay at license tax of 250 an nually. The Virginia Club and Board of Trade come within the provisions of ,his section. The Orkney Springs Hotel property, situate at Orkney Springs, Shenan doahcounty, a popular resort, formerly owned b y Mrs. Henrietta Stuart, ol Washington, has been exchanged to Mr. Romaine Dally, of Washington, D. C., for the Imperial Hotel of Pe tersburg. G. T. Alphin has sold his farm near the mouth of Kerrs creek, Rock bridge county, to Frank Brown, of. Lexington, for 2500. It contains about 76 acres. Mr. Alphin has purchased a farm for 3500. News has been received in Lexington of the death by yellow fever of Rev. Charles R. Morton, a missionary in the Southern Presbyterian Church in Brazil. Mr. M. C. Bayless, 52 years old. ? farmer of near Winchester, died Thurs day night. A widow and four children survive him. The capital stock to the Peoples Na tional Bank of Roanoke has been over subscribed by 10,000. More than two- thirds is taken by local merchants ant1 business men. Dr. George H. P. Cole a well-known local capitalist, was slat ed for president. Frost is reported from the Bac Creek pippen belt, but the crop was but slightly injured. The apple prospects in Roanoke, Bedford, Franklin anc Campbell county have never been bet ter. The lumber steamer Francis H. Leg gett sailed for San Francisco. The ves sel has just been completed at New port News, and is for the redwood lum ber trade in California. She takes ou two American locomotives for Japanese consignees, and has also on board a lo of steel rails. The Finance Committee of the Pe tersburg City Council opened the bidt for 190,030 4 per cent. 40-year refund jjig bonds and awarded them to lo cal bidders at an average price of 103.59 The Petersburg Savings and Insurance Company bid par for the entire amount These bonds are issued to refund a likt amount of 8 per cent, bonds due on th first of May. William Englcnian, a farmer o Greenville. Augusta county, was throwr from his horse a few lays ago and i now in a critical condition. Mr. En  glenian wal sitting on his horse whili pouring some feed into a hogpen, wher the horse made a sudden leap. Mr Engleman was thrown headforemost tc the ground and struck, a sharp stake There is little hope of his recovery. The Washington and Southwesterr vestibule limited No. 38 of the Southerr Railroad ran into the rear end of 1 freight train near Lynchburg. The en gine was demolished, two mail and twe freight cars were completely burned and the engineer of the passenger Charley R. Kinney, of Thomasville N. C., was killed. No 38 was goin down a heavy grade at the time. Or seeing the freight ahead of him. Kin ney reversed his engine and jumped As he struck the-ground the front jmi car turned over on him, killing hitr instantly.

Pearson, each to Chas Oelkers, Mary Cox, each 12 George A. Slusher and Lewis Hood, each 8 John Newton, 6 Martha Lovern, Har riet C. H. S. Peyton, o! Blackburn, has been elected superintendent of the Swee Briar Institute Farm. This property left by the late Mrs. Indiana Fletchei Williams for the establishment of r school for girls, comprises 3060 acres, 1050 acres of which came to the estatf through the death of Mrs. W. A. New man, which occurred last week. _ Mrs Newman had a life interest in th Mount St- Angelo plantation, also own ed by Mrs. Williams, and under the wil it passed to Sweet Briar on her death Sweet Briar has lost thousands of dol lars through lawsuits, but after the set tlement of all of them the institute has left 600,000, of which 200,oco is now being spent in the erection of handsome buildings. The principal buildings wil be completed by January 1. Alonzo Misick, an influential citizer of Finney, Russell county, met a horri ble death- He was driving a two-horse team home from Finney, and when neat the railroad crossing his team became frightened and started to run. He lock ed wheels with another wagon on the railroad track. In a moment before the engineer could reverse the locomotive 01 turn on the airbrakes, the two teams were struck fairly, and Misick and his horses were terribly mangled- Tht horses of the other team were also killed, but the occupant of the wagon jumped and escaped unhurt- Misick was 41 years old and leaves a widow and six children. The jury which heard the evidence in the case of Alfred _ Sandridge at Rich mond, accused of killing his sweetheart, Miss Nannie Morris, and whose plea was temporary insanity, reached an agreement- Sandridge .was found guilty of murder in the second degree. He was sentenced to a term of 10 years in the penitentiary. His counsel made no motion for an appeal- It is understood that the jury stood first seven for hang ing and five for some lesser punishment- Mr. John Blue, aged .74 years, died at Romney from heart failure- For a num ber of years preceding his death, _ Mr Blue was affected with elephantiasis, which caused the skin of his face, hands and feet to thicken to abnormal propor tions. Each of his fingers, was as large as an ordinary mans wrist. He .was a well-known Confederate and a writer of Civil War sketches- He leaves six chil dren. Col- James W- White, a well-known merchant of Richmond, and formerly member of the Board of Aldermen, died suddenly on the steamer going from Baltimore to Mathews county. Mr- White was on a trip for rest and pleas ure and seemed in usual health. His remains will be brought here- Mr. James Cole. Jr., a one-legged Confederate veteran, died at his home, Wicomico, Northumberland county. He was at one time Commissioner of Rev enue of his county. Governor Montague issued a procla mation to the effect that the city of Man chester is now of the first class, and en titled to all the benefits accruing to such cities under the constitution. A recent orivate census disclosed the fact that Manchester has 10,678 inhabitants- Man chester, therefore, has a greater onus upon her to protect property when the cars are run again through her streets- An eastbottnd freight train on the 1 James River division of the! Chesapeake  and Ohio railway was wrecked neat Majors, about twenty-three miles west of Lynchburg. Three colored miners or !he train were killed. The others .were so badly disfigured that they could not be identified. The joint Legislative commission named at the recent session to considet and report the advisability of breaking the Baylor survey of oyster lands has returned to Richmond from a two weeks trip in the Waters of Eastern Virginia, The commission will make no report until it-has made another trip, on August 11, to inspect the alleged barren oystei rocks. William Johnson, who was employee at the Seaboard Air Line Railroad shop! in Portsmouth at the time of the big fin recently, has been adjudged insane Since the fire Mr. Johnson continuall raves about it. He was sent to the asy lum at Williamsburg. The striking marine engineers havi preferred charges against the Merchant! and Miners Line, Old Dominion Line Southern Railway and the Greenleaf Johnson Company. The engineers alleg that these companies are running ves sels with one set of men while the fed ernl law requires two sets. Mr- W- E. Carson, junior member o the Carson Lime Company, of Riverton while superintending the transfer o stone from their quarry to the kiln, wa struck by a truck and knocked down ar embankment, landing on y an engine 2 feet below and breaking his left arm anc dislocating his right shoulder. The local-option election in Fred ericksburg in which some interest hat been felt for weeks, passed off quietly The wets won by a majority of 218. The Norfolk marine engineers, whe have been on strike, and the shipown -rs have agreed on all but one point. The strike would be settled but for the failure to agree as to the men who have been brought to Norfolk. The engi neers demand that the new men shall be sent away and that the strikers shall be returned to their former positions The Sidney P. Laughlin Presbyterian Chapel, erected by Messrs. Williams George A. and Samuel Laughlin, of Ohio, to the memory of their parents, was dedicated at Woodstock. The pre sentation address to the Presbyterian Church was made by Mr. George A Laughlin and the address of acceptance was made by the pastor, Rev. P. D. Stephenson. The chapel was recently erected at a cost of 8000. The Cannon Ball Norfolk and Western Train was wrecked at Dun lops Station and Engineer Harry Cov ington and Fireman Robert Covington killed and six other persons injured. By his will the late Henry T. Sutton, of Surry Courthouse, left his 25,000 estate to his aunt, Mrs. R. P. Jones Mr. James Cuthbert, of Petersburg, is administrator. Troop B, Cavalry, Virginia Volun teers, were inspected at Surry Court house by Captain Bishop, of Fortress I Monroe, United States Army. Old Point Comfort is now one of the gayest of the Virginia resorts, as 3 number of nsvv vessels sre 3 t smenor in Hampton Roads. 1 _   j  __ ___ 1

document.text: Virginia Adams Rosser, 80, of Appomattox, died at 11 p.m. Saturday at her residence. She was the widow of J. Morton Rosser, Sr. Born in Charlotte County, she was the daughter of the late John Robert Adams and Lelia Barnes Adams. She was a member of Liberty Baptist Sunday School and the Eva Saunders Circle of Liberty Baptist Church. She was a member of the United Daugh ters of the Confederacy and she and her husband operated the Rosser Milling Co. until 1944. She was a retired employee of the Appomattox Garment Co. She is survived by a son, Jee Mqrton Rosser, Jr. of Appomattox two grandchil dren, Susan Marie Rosser and J. M. Bud Rosser, both of Appomattox, and several niec es and nephews. Funeral services were con ducted Tuesday at 2 p.m. from Robinson Funeral Home with burial in Liberty Cemetery.

Come, anyway, Everybody come by 130 and let us welcome those boys who have returned, sending greet ings to those who have not,and giving thanks that our dollars have helped to save the lives of our soldiers. document.text: upon the arm of the president pro  tempore of the senate. The president and the president elect sat in the first row of seats di rectly in front and almost under the desk of the presiding officer. In the same row, but to their left, were the vice-president-elect and two former vice-presidents of the United States, Levi P. Morton of New York and Ad- lai A. Stevenson of Illinois. When the distinguished company en tered the chamber the senate was still under its old organization. The oath of office was immediately admin istered to Vice-President-elect  Mar shall, who thereupon became Vice- President Marshall. The prayer of the day was given by the chaplain of the senate, Rev. Ulysses, G. B. Pierce, pas tor of All Souls Unitarian church, of which President Taft has been a mem ber. After the prayer the vice-presi dent administered the oath of office to all the newly chcsen senators, and therewith the senate of the United States passed for the first time in years into the control of the Demo cratic party. Procession to East Portico. Immediately after the senate cere monies a procession was formed to march to the platform of the east por tico of the capitol, where Woodrow Wilson was to take the oath. The pro cession included the president and the president-elect, members of the Su preme court, both houses of congress, all of the foreign ambassadors, all of the heads of the executive depart ments, many governors of states and territories, Admiral Dewey of the navy and several high officers of the sea service, the chief of staff of the army and many distinguished persons from civil life. They were followed by the members of the press and by those persons who had succeeded in secur ing seats in the senate galleries to witness the days proceedings.  When President Taft and the presi dent-elect emerged from the capitol on to the portico they saw in front of them, reaching far back into the park to the east, an immense con course of citizens. In the narrow line between the onlookers and the plat form on which Mr. Wilson was to take the oath, were drawn up the cadets of the two greatest government schools, West Point and Adnapolis, and flanking them were bodies of reg ulars and of national guardsmen. The whole scene waa charged with color and with life. On reaching the platform the presi dent and president-elect took the seats reserved for them, seats which were flanked by many rows of benches rising tier on tier for the accommoda tion of the friends and families of the officers of the government and of the press. Mr. Wilson Takes the Oath. The instant that Mr. Taft and Mr. Wilson came within sight of the crowd there was a great outburst of ap plause, and the military bands struck quickly into The Star Spangled Ban ner. Only a few bars of the music were played and then soldiers and ci vilians became silent to witness re spectfully the oath taking and to listen to the address which followed. The chief justice of the Supreme court delivered the oath to the presi dent-elect, who, uttering the words, i will, became president of the United States. As soon as this cere mony was completed Woodrow Wilson delivered his inaugural address, his fitst speech to his fellow countrymen In the capacity of their chief execu tive. At the conclusion of the speech the bands played once more, and William Howard Taft, now ex-president of the United States, entered a carriage with the new president and, reversing the order of an hour before, sat on the

document.text: U D C M e t April 20th a bridal luncheon at the Ivy Post in honor of Mrs. Herncalls niece, Miss Peggie Sue Stanley, and the attendants in her forthcoming marriage to Way ne Simpson.
